answers.title: How to map tenant request to the root page of application in spring boot using spring webflux webfilter
answers.body:
Related to: Spring webflux: redirect http to https

A better solution than changing the direction of the request internally.

    @Override
    public Mono<Void> filter(ServerWebExchange exchange, WebFilterChain chain) {
        URI uri = exchange.getRequest().getURI();

        if (uri.getPath().contains("tenant")) {
            try {
                URI mutatedUri = new URI(
                    uri.getScheme(),
                    uri.getUserInfo(),
                    uri.getHost(),
                    uri.getPort(),
                    "/",
                    uri.getQuery(),
                    uri.getFragment()
                );
                ServerHttpResponse response = exchange.getResponse();
                response.setStatusCode(HttpStatus.MOVED_PERMANENTLY);
                response.getHeaders().setLocation(mutatedUri);
                return Mono.empty();
            } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
                return Mono.error(new IllegalStateException(e.getMessage(), e));
            }
        }

        return chain.filter(exchange);
    }

items.title: How to map tenant request to the root page of application in spring boot using spring webflux webfilter
items.body:
I am using spring webflux and webfilter in my spring boot application and i'm bundling angular and spring boot into a single jar file and i am able to access angular at "/".

My use case is i want to support multi-tenant and when i access my application using "localhost:8080/tenant/tenantname/" it is considered as new tenant with name "tenantname" and i need to open the home page of angular which is at "/" by keeping the uri in the search bar as "localhost:8080/tenant/tenantname/".

So to achieve it i have implemented a webfilter and modifying the path to "/" if the uri has "tenant", but when we send the modified uri to chain.filter(), the uri in the search box is getting to "localhost:8080/" i dont want it happen i want the uri in search box should be same "localhost:8080/tenant/tenantname/".

@Component
public class TenantFilter implements WebFilter {
    @Override
    public Mono<Void> filter(ServerWebExchange exchange, WebFilterChain chain) {
        String uri = exchange.getRequest().getURI().getPath();
        ServerWebExchange updatedExchange = exchange;
        if(uri.contains("tenant")){
             updatedExchange = exchange.mutate().request(request->{
                request.path("/");
            }).build();
        }
        return chain.filter(updatedExchange);
    }
}

In my old POC i have use servlet filter it was working fine there.

Servlet filter example:

@Override
    public void doFilter(ServletRequest request, ServletResponse response, FilterChain chain) throws IOException, ServletException {
       
        HttpServletRequest httpRequest = (HttpServletRequest) request;
        String requestURI = httpRequest.getRequestURI();
        if(requestURI.contains("/tenant")){
            request.getRequestDispatcher(URLDecoder.decode(uri, "UTF-8")).forward(request, response);
        }
        chain.doFilter(request, response);
    }

in servlet filter i have use request.getRequestDispatcher().forward(request,response). is there anything same in spring webflux webfilter or do i need to change anything in my webFlux WebFilter.

answers.body_markdown:
OpenApi generator uses mustache templates to generate code. For Spring you find these templates here:

https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/tree/master/modules/openapi-generator/src/main/resources/JavaSpring

In `api.mustache` you find `{{>headerParams}}`. This is a mustache partial that is a way to reuse the same template code in multiple places. Here it means, include the `headerParams.mustache` at this place.

In `headerParams.mustache`, you will find that headers are included one by one. 

In summary, it is not possible to to generate a Map of multiple header parameters (at least not by default configuration mechanism).

https://github.com/OpenAPITools/openapi-generator/tree/master/modules/openapi-generator/src/main/resources/JavaSpring

In api.mustache you find {{>headerParams}}. This is a mustache partial that is a way to reuse the same template code in multiple places. Here it means, include the headerParams.mustache at this place.

In headerParams.mustache, you will find that headers are included one by one.

In summary, it is not possible to to generate a Map of multiple header parameters (at least not by default configuration mechanism).

answers.title: Passing Java Function to KFunction
answers.body:
You can make a Kotlin wrapper of the KFunction-accepting function, that takes a function type instead:

fun registerHelper(value: (Value) -> Unit) {
   register(value::invoke)
}

This can then be called from the Java code:

public class Test {
    public void launch() {
        registerHelper(Test::test);
    }
    @Subscriber
    public static Unit test(Value data) {
        System.out.println("Hello world!");
        return Unit.INSTANCE;
    }
}

However, if registerHelper needs to access the name of test, or the annotations on it, rather than just call it, it is a lot harder.

One way I can think of is what you'd do in kotlin, when you want to convert a java.lang.reflect.Method into a KFunction. You'd use kotlinFunction, right?

The kotlinFunction property corresponds to a static method called ReflectJvmMapping.getKotlinFunction in Java.

You can get the test method as a java.lang.reflect.Method, then use that to convert to a KFunction:

var testClass = Test.class;
var method = testClass.getMethod("test", Value.class);

// note the unchecked cast here, which is safe as long as you got the correct method
Event.register((KFunction<Unit>) ReflectJvmMapping.getKotlinFunction(method));

Since the implementation of getKotlinFunction uses Kotlin reflection to find the function again, it might be better if you convert Test.class to a Kotlin class first, and then use Kotlin reflection directly.

var testClassKotlin = JvmClassMappingKt.getKotlinClass(Test.class);
var kfunction = KClasses.getFunctions(testClassKotlin).stream()
    // use whatever criteria to find the method you want
    .filter(x -> x.getName().equals("test"))
    .findFirst().get();

That said, this is not how the Kotlin compiler internally makes a KFunction, when you write a function reference. The kotlin compiler actually creates a subclass of kotlin.jvm.internal.FunctionReferenceImpl. If you want to do what the compiler does, which I don't really recommend:

// yes, implementing the raw type of Function1 is necessary.
class SomeInnerClass extends FunctionReferenceImpl implements kotlin.jvm.functions.Function1{

    public SomeInnerClass() {
        // here you need to pass in the arty, declared class, name,
        // JVM signature, and some flags too
        super(1, Test.class, "test", "test(Lyourpackage/Value;)Lkotlin/Unit;", 0);
        // For what the flags mean, see 
        // https://github.com/JetBrains/kotlin/blob/master/libraries/stdlib/jvm/runtime/kotlin/jvm/internal/FunctionReference.java#L16
    }

    @Override
    public Unit invoke(Object value) {
        return Test.test((Value)value);
    }

}

Then an instance of this is passed to register.

comments.body_markdown: Does python-oracledb install cleanly in AWS Glue?  If so, then you could use this API instead of the heavy-weight 'call java from python' approach. The default install just uses the latter.)

comments.body_markdown: google **"IndexOutOfBoundsException"**
comments.body: google "IndexOutOfBoundsException"

comments.body_markdown: The difference is that one is used in case of n Array, the other is not.
comments.body: The difference is that one is used in case of n Array, the other is not.

answers.body_markdown:
`IndexOutOfBoundsException` is the super class of `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException` (thrown when accessing invalid index in a array) and `StringIndexOutOfBoundsException` (thrown when accessing invalid index in a String).

Instances of the base class `IndexOutOfBoundsException` itself are thrown when accessing invalid indices of Lists.

The Javadoc of some methods that throw `IndexOutOfBoundsException` or its sub-classes contains the base class. For example, `String.charAt` is documented to be throwing `IndexOutOfBoundsException` when it actually throws the sub-class `StringIndexOutOfBoundsException`.
answers.title: Difference between ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException and IndexOutOfBoundsException?
answers.body:
IndexOutOfBoundsException is the super class of ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException (thrown when accessing invalid index in a array) and StringIndexOutOfBoundsException (thrown when accessing invalid index in a String).

Instances of the base class IndexOutOfBoundsException itself are thrown when accessing invalid indices of Lists.

The Javadoc of some methods that throw IndexOutOfBoundsException or its sub-classes contains the base class. For example, String.charAt is documented to be throwing IndexOutOfBoundsException when it actually throws the sub-class StringIndexOutOfBoundsException.

answers.body_markdown: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException indicates the illegal index in its message.
answers.title: Difference between ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException and IndexOutOfBoundsException?
answers.body: ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException indicates the illegal index in its message.

answers.body_markdown:
From docs.oracle.com documentation pages,

>[IndexOutOfBoundsException][1] :Thrown to indicate that an index of some sort (such as to an array, to a string, or to a vector) is out of range.


 `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`, `StringIndexOutOfBoundsException` 
  are two classes, which have implemented `IndexOutOfBoundsException`.

>[ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException][2]: Thrown to indicate that an array has been accessed with an illegal index. The index is either negative or greater than or equal to the size of the array.

>[StringIndexOutOfBoundsException][3]:Thrown by String methods to indicate that an index is either negative or greater than the size of the string. For some methods such as the charAt method, this exception also is thrown when the index is equal to the size of the string.




  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/IndexOutOfBoundsException.html
  [2]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.html
  [3]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/lang/StringIndexOutOfBoundsException.html
answers.title: Difference between ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException and IndexOutOfBoundsException?
answers.body:
From docs.oracle.com documentation pages,

IndexOutOfBoundsException :Thrown to indicate that an index of some sort (such as to an array, to a string, or to a vector) is out of range.

ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException, StringIndexOutOfBoundsException are two classes, which have implemented IndexOutOfBoundsException.

ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException: Thrown to indicate that an array has been accessed with an illegal index. The index is either negative or greater than or equal to the size of the array.

StringIndexOutOfBoundsException:Thrown by String methods to indicate that an index is either negative or greater than the size of the string. For some methods such as the charAt method, this exception also is thrown when the index is equal to the size of the string.

answers.body_markdown:
Basically, if you go out of bounds for an array or String, you will get the ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException or the StringIndexOutOfBoundsException. 
For a LinkedList though or some other Collection, you will get the more general IndexOutOfBoundsException.
answers.title: Difference between ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException and IndexOutOfBoundsException?
